dAmn.name: dAmn
dAmn.description: This module holds the dAmn extension.

Chatterbox.name: Chatterbox
Chatterbox.description: Chatterbox is wsc's default UI library.

dAmn.Extension.name: dAmn.Extension
dAmn.Extension.description:
The dAmn extension makes the client work with dAmn. This extension also implements
various other features to improve on the user experience.

dAmn.avatar.name: dAmn.avatar
dAmn.avatar.description: This object provides a few helper functions relating to deviantART avatars.

dAmn.Stash.name: dAmn.Stash
dAmn.Stash.description:
Extension to handle stash links posted in the chat. Provides some helper functions
to meet this end as well.

dAmn.TablumpString.name: dAmn.TablumpString
dAmn.TablumpString.description:
Represents a string that possibly contains tablumps.
Use different object methods to render the tablumps differently.

params.name: parser
params.description: A reference to a tablumps parser.

Chatterbox.UI.name: Chatterbox.UI
Chatterbox.UI.description:
This object is the platform for the wsc UI. Everything can be used and
loaded from here.

params.name: client
params.description: The client that this UI is attached to.

params.name: view
params.description: Base jQuery object to use for the UI. Any empty div will do.

params.name: options
params.description: Custom settings to use for the UI.

params.name: mozilla
params.description: Is the browser in use made by Mozilla?

Chatterbox.UI.sound.name: Chatterbox.UI.sound
Chatterbox.UI.sound.description:
Sound bank.

Play and manage UI sounds. So far, Chatterbox includes these sounds:

     * click

To play a sound clip, call the method of the same name. For example, to
play the `click` sound, call `ui.sound.click()`.

Note that the sound methods are not documented as they are created on
the fly by the `add` method.

params.name: ns
params.description: The name of the channel this object will represent.

params.name: hidden
params.description: Should the channel's tab be visible?

Chatterbox.Chatbook.name: Chatterbox.Chatbook
Chatterbox.Chatbook.description: Object for managing the chatbook portion of the UI.

Chatterbox.Control.name: Chatterbox.Control
Chatterbox.Control.description: This object provides an interface for the chat input panel.

Chatterbox.Navigation.name: Chatterbox.Navigation
Chatterbox.Navigation.description: Navigation UI element. Provides helpers for controlling the chat navigation.

Chatterbox.Pager.name: Chatterbox.Pager
Chatterbox.Pager.description:
Pager

Used for giving the user notifications.

Chatterbox.Popup.name: Chatterbox.Popup
Chatterbox.Popup.description:
Popup window base class.

Should allow people to easily create popups... or something.
Subclasses of the popups should provide a way of closing the popup, or
maybe I could change things around a bit so there's always a close button in
the top right corner. That said, the settings window looks good with the
close button at the bottom. Maybe make that configurable. Use a flag to
determine whether or not this class applies the close function or not?

Chatterbox.Settings.name: Chatterbox.Settings
Chatterbox.Settings.description:
Settings popup window.
Provides stuff for doing things. Yay.

Chatterbox.Settings.Config.name: Chatterbox.Settings.Config
Chatterbox.Settings.Config.description:
Settings options object.
Extensions can configure the settings window with this shit yo.

wsc.Channel.name: wsc.Channel
wsc.Channel.description:
Chat channel object.
Manages channel events and data, and acts as a thin wrapper for the
channel's UI object.

params.name: hidden
params.description: Should the channel tab be hidden?

wsc.Client.name: wsc.Client
wsc.Client.description:
An entire chat client. Instances of this object orchestrate the operation of
the client. Other objects are loaded in to control different parts of the client. These
components can be reasonably swapped out, assuming they provide the same functionality.

wsc.defaults.Extension.name: wsc.defaults.Extension
wsc.defaults.Extension.description: This extension implements most of the default commands for wsc.

EventEmitter.name: EventEmitter
EventEmitter.description: Event emitter object emits events and stuff.

wsc.Flow.name: wsc.Flow
wsc.Flow.description:
Control the client's program flow. This object determines how the client responds to
certain events.

StringSet.name: StringSet
StringSet.description:
Sets of unique strings.

Strings in the set are stored lower case.

wsc.Protocol.LogMessage.name: wsc.Protocol.LogMessage
wsc.Protocol.LogMessage.description: Log message object represents a log message.

wsc.Storage.name: wsc.Storage
wsc.Storage.description:
Storage object.

This class is a light wrapper around localStorage. Keys are given namespaces, to avoid
interfering with the data of other applications. This feature also allows us to create
"folders".

params.name: namespace
params.description: Storage namespace to apply to keys

classitems.description: BDS Event handlers.
dAmn Event handlers
Fetch stash data.
Render a stash thumb.

classitems.name:
html

Render the tablumps as HTML entities.

text

Render the tablumps in plain text where possible. Some tablumps appear as
HTML entities even through this.

ansi

Render the tablumps with ANSI escape sequences.

For this rendering method to really be worth it, I'll actually have to move
away from the simple regex.

classitems.description: States for the parser.

This object holds each tablump's parsing and rendering rules. For each tablump, there is a key, which is the tablump's head, or "tag". The entry is an array with the number of arguments in the tablump, followed by different renderers. As a generalisation, it looks like this: this.lumps[tag] = [ arguments, render_text, render_html, render_ansi ]; Renderers can be formatting strings or functions. All renderers other than the first one are optional. If a particular render is not available, the rendering step falls back to the first renderer in the Array. As a brief example, this is what the img tag's entry looks like: this.lumps['&img\t'] = [ 3, ''];
classitems.name: lumps

classitems.description: I should probably deprecate this. Sets the rendering map to the given map.
classitems.name: registerMap

classitems.description: Add the given rendering items to the parser's render map.
classitems.name: extend

classitems.description: Get all the default nonsense.
classitems.name: defaultMap

classitems.description:
Parse a message into tokens and return it as a
{{#crossLink "dAmn.TablumpString"}}{{/crossLink}} object.
classitems.name: parse

classitems.description: Parse a message possibly containing tablumps into tokens.
classitems.name: tokenise

classitems.description:
Render tablumps in a given format.

Here, the flag should be a number, and defines the index of the renderer
to use when rendering a tablump. Setting `flag` to 0 will result in the
first renderer being used. In the render map, the plain text renderers come
first, and also act as a default.

Setting `flag` to 1 causes the parser to render tablumps as HTML elements
where possible. Setting `flag` to 2 causes the parser to render tablumps as
ANSI escape sequence formatted strings where possible.
classitems.name: render

params.name: flag
params.description: Determines how the message should be rendered

classitems.description: Render a single tablump.

classitems.description:
Mapping object.

This object determines how each protocol packet should be mapped from a `packet object`
to an `event object`. For each packet, there is an entry, where the key is the
{{#crossLink "wsc.Protocol/event:method"}}event name{{/crossLink}} of the packet.

Each entry is an array. The array consists of names under which to store packet data.
The array is of the structure `[ param, args, body ]`. All items are optional, but
positional. To discard a particular piece of data, `null` can be used.

When `args` is present it must be an array. This array names the arguments to store.
Each item in the `args` array can be a string or a pair of strings. For strings,
the corresponding packet argument is stored using its own name. For pairs, the packet
argument named by the first string is stored using the second string as the key.

When `body` is present, it can either be a string or an array. If a string is provided,
the entire body is stored using the string as the key. If an array is provided, it
treated as another mapping array. This is handled recursively.

Keys in the mapping array can start with an asterisks (`*`). This indicates that the
value is a formatted string and needs to be parsed using a
{{#crossLink "wsc.MessageParser"}}message parser{{/crossLink}}. The asterisks is
removed from the key in the final object.

As an example, property packets use this mapping array:

     this.maps['property'] = ['ns', ['p', 'by', 'ts'], '*value' ];

When mapping a property packet, the returned object looks like the following:
     
     {
         "name": "property",
         "ns": pkt.param,
         "p": pkt.arg.p,
         "by": pkt.arg.by,
         "ts": pkt.arg.ts,
         "value": pkt.body
     }

For an example of arguments being mapped to different keys, kick
(error) packets use this mapping array:

     this.maps['kick'] = ['ns', [['u', 'user'], 'e']];

For this array, the returned object looks like the following:
     
     {
         "name": "kick",
         "ns": pkt.param,
         "user": pkt.arg.u,
         "e": pkt.body
     }
classitems.name: maps

classitems.description: Messages object. This object determines how each protocol packet should be rendered based data from an `event object`. For each packet, there is an entry, where the key is the {{#crossLink "wsc.Protocol/event:method"}}event name{{/crossLink}} of the packet. Each entry is an array. The array consists of options for rendering and logging. The array is of the structure `[ renderers, monitor, global ]`. All items are optional, but positional. There are default options that can be used. When `renderers` is present it must be an array. This array contains renderers for different kinds of formats. Renderers can be either a formatted string or a callback that returns a string. There must be at least one renderer, for text output. Otherwise the array should contain a renderer for text ouput, a renderer for HTML output, and a renderer for ANSI output. If a renderer is missing then everything falls back to text renderer. The `monitor` option determines whether or not to display the log message in the monitor channel. The default for this is `false`. The `global` option determines whether or not to display the log message in every open channel. The default for this is also `false`. An example for an entry in this object: { 'join': [ [ '** Join {ns}: "{e}" *', '** Join {ns}: "{e}" *' ], true ] } This shows how the join packet will render in the monitor channel. If a channel is set to display in the monitor channel, then it should not be displayed in the event channel. At the moment, we only have to render using HTML, so the `renderers` array in the entries are only HTML renderers at the moment. No array, just formatting strings. To display absolutely nothing for an event, the whole entry can simply be `null`.
classitems.name: messages
